::: {.cell}

:::


# Blizzard salary

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
Use the following visualizations for Question \_\_ through \_\_.
:::


::: {.cell}

:::


In 2020, employees of Blizzard Entertainment circulated a spreadsheet to anonymously share salaries and recent pay increases amidst rising tension in the video game industry over wage disparities and executive compensation. @fig-blizzard-1 and @fig-blizzard-2 contain plots that display the distributions of annual salaries of hourly and salaried Blizzard employees.

The name of the data frame used for this analysis is `blizzard_salary` and the relevant variables are:

-   `percent_incr`: Raise given in July 2020, as percent increase with values ranging from 1 (1% increase to 21.5 (21.5% increase)

-   `salary_type`: Type of salary, with levels `Hourly` and `Salaried`

-   `annual_salary`: Annual salary, in USD, with values ranging from \$50,939 to \$216,856.

-   `performance_rating`: Most recent review performance rating, with levels `High`, `Successful`, `Top`, and `Developing`

The top five rows of `blizzard_salary` are shown below:


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 5 × 4
  percent_incr salary_type annual_salary performance_rating
         <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> <chr>             
1            1 Salaried               1  High              
2            1 Salaried               1  Successful        
3            1 Salaried               1  High              
4            1 Hourly             33987. Successful        
5           NA Hourly             34798. High              
```


:::
:::


And the bottom five rows are show below as well:


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 5 × 4
  percent_incr salary_type annual_salary performance_rating
         <dbl> <chr>               <dbl> <chr>             
1            1 Salaried            43465 Successful        
2            1 Salaried            54787 Successful        
3           16 Salaried            65745 High              
4            1 Salaried            84008 Successful        
5            4 Salaried            87298 <NA>              
```


:::
:::


1.  @fig-blizzard-hist-1 and @fig-blizzard-hist-2 show the distributions of annual salaries of hourly and salaried workers. The two figures show the same data, with the facets organized across rows and across columns.


    ::: {.cell}
    ::: {.cell-output-display}
    ![Distribution of annual salaries of Blizzard employees, Option 1](exam-1-review_files/figure-html/fig-blizzard-hist-1-1.png){#fig-blizzard-hist-1 width=672}
    :::
    :::

    ::: {.cell}
    ::: {.cell-output-display}
    ![Distribution of annual salaries of Blizzard employees, Option 2](exam-1-review_files/figure-html/fig-blizzard-hist-2-1.png){#fig-blizzard-hist-2 width=960}
    :::
    :::


    Which of the two figures is better for comparing the median annual salaries of hourly and salaried workers.

    a.  @fig-blizzard-hist-1
    b.  @fig-blizzard-hist-2

2.  Suppose your teammate wrote the following code as part of their analysis of the data.


    ::: {.cell}
    
    :::


    They then printed out the results shown below. Unfortunately one of the number got erased from the printout, it's indicated with `_____` below.

    ```         
    # A tibble: 2 × 3
      salary_type mean_annual_salary median_annual_salary
      <chr>                    <dbl>                <dbl>
    1 Hourly                  63003.               54246.
    2 Salaried                90183.               _____
    ```

    Which of the following is the best estimate for that erased value?

    a.  30,000
    b.  50,000
    c.  80,000
    d.  100,000

3.  Which distribution has a higher standard deviation?

    a.  Hourly workers
    b.  Salaried workers
    c.  Roughly the same

4.  Which of the following alternate plots would also be useful for visualizing the distributions of annual salaries of hourly and salaried workers?

    I.  Box plot
    II. Density plot
    III. Pie chart
    IV. Waffle chart


    ```{=html}
    <!-- -->
    ```

    a.  I
    b.  I and II
    c.  I, II, and III
    d.  III and IV

5.
